ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt how to organize my ideas and find the larger arguments from a long text.

- writing skills
- general political knowledge 
- specific focus on liberalism and critiques of liberalism
I learned a lot about the development of political philosophy, and improved my writing skills.
I learned about the connection between Roman and Medieval European history and politics and the history and politics of the 20th century.
I developed my understanding of modern thinkers and how many of the world's current ideologies came to be.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There could be more student engagement but I also loved how Prof. Kreiner was always prepared with notes. I liked getting the questions ahead of time because it helped focus my reading and follow his train of thought more.
The reading load is quite heavy and towards the end of the semester it is difficult to expect students to go through every reading in detail. Course engagement suffers as a result.
The course had no weaknesses, and I think Professor Kreiner did a great job of explaining the texts and concepts.
The class environment was very welcoming, so I always felt like it was a safe space where we could exchange our ideas. Professor Kreiner was also chill and friendly.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you want to do DS!
Yes, but be prepared to read a lot. Also, Spring semester DS is heavy on political philosophy. There is very little actual history or historical thought.
I would recommend this course to a student interested in political thought.
